articles.title: EU countries are spending more on education again
articles.summary: The share of public spending, according to a new EU report, has not yet reached pre-Corona levels. Austria is in the lower midfield.
articles.content:
The share of public spending, according to a new EU report, has not yet reached pre-Corona levels. Austria is in the lower midfield.

Brussels – According to the report “Investing in Education 2025” published by the EU Commission on Wednesday in Brussels, public investment in education has recovered after the Covid-19 pandemic. However, it has not yet reached pre-crisis levels. Overall, EU countries spent 806 billion euros on education in 2023. The differences in Europe are significant; Austria ranks at the lower end of the scale with just under 10 percent of public spending.

National education spending reached an EU average of 9.6 percent of total public expenditure and 4.7 percent of gross domestic product (GDP). The largest share of public spending on education is allocated by Estonia (14.5 percent), Sweden (14.4), and Latvia (14), while the smallest share is by Italy (7.3 percent), Greece (8), and Romania (8.1). Relative to GDP, Sweden spends the most on the education of its citizens at 7.2 percent; at the bottom is Ireland with 2.8 percent. Austria reaches about 5 percent.

The lion’s share goes to schools

According to the report, the lion’s share of public education spending goes to schools across the EU: In 2023, it was more than 70 percent. This is roughly evenly distributed between pre-primary and primary schools (35 percent) and secondary schools (37 percent), while tertiary education accounted for 16 percent of public spending. The remainder goes to other educational offerings. The distribution in Austria follows the EU average.

The EU Commission also emphasizes the importance of education in its report: According to its estimates, the GDP of European countries could be 8 to 10 percent higher than current forecasts by 2030 if more people had sufficient basic skills. Furthermore, individuals with a higher level of education tend to earn more: Just one additional year of education could increase a person’s income in Europe by 7 percent.

“High-quality education is crucial for addressing demographic change in Europe, including the challenge of skilled labor shortages. An aging population threatens to lead to a decline in the working population and a burden on public finances. Investments in education, especially for younger generations, are essential to maintain economic dynamism,” the Commission appeals to EU states to invest more. (28.08.2025)

This represents a positive real-world impact with meaningful scope for the general public, supported by detailed data and context.
articles.personality_title: EU countries increase education spending but still below pre-pandemic levels
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – After the Covid-19 pandemic, many European Union (EU) countries reduced public spending on education. A new report shows how these countries are now investing more again to support schools and learners.

**What happened** – The EU Commission published a report called “Investing in Education 2025” on August 28, 2025. It found that EU countries spent a total of 806 billion euros on education in 2023. On average, education took up 9.6 percent of public spending and 4.7 percent of each country’s economy (GDP). Austria spends just under 10 percent of public money on education, placing it in the lower middle compared to other countries. Estonia, Sweden, and Latvia spend the most, while Italy, Greece, and Romania spend the least.

**Impact** – Most of the money goes to schools, with over 70 percent of education funds used for pre-primary, primary, and secondary schools. Investing in education is important because it can help European economies grow by 8 to 10 percent by 2030 if more people gain basic skills. Also, people with more education usually earn more money – one extra year of schooling can increase income by 7 percent.

**What's next step** – The EU Commission encourages countries to keep investing in education, especially to prepare young people for future jobs. This is important because Europe’s population is getting older, which means fewer workers and more pressure on public services. Better education can help keep economies strong despite these changes.

**One-sentence takeaway** – EU countries are increasing education spending after the pandemic, aiming to boost skills and support economic growth, but more investment is still needed to reach past levels.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les pays de l’UE augmentent les dépenses en éducation mais restent en dessous des niveaux d’avant la pandémie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après la pandémie de Covid-19, de nombreux pays de l’Union européenne (UE) ont réduit leurs dépenses publiques en éducation. Un nouveau rapport montre que ces pays investissent à nouveau davantage pour soutenir les écoles et les élèves.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La Commission européenne a publié le 28 août 2025 un rapport intitulé « Investir dans l’éducation 2025 ». Il révèle que les pays de l’UE ont dépensé au total 806 milliards d’euros pour l’éducation en 2023. En moyenne, l’éducation représentait 9,6 % des dépenses publiques et 4,7 % de l’économie de chaque pays (PIB). L’Autriche consacre un peu moins de 10 % de ses fonds publics à l’éducation, ce qui la place dans la moyenne basse par rapport aux autres pays. L’Estonie, la Suède et la Lettonie dépensent le plus, tandis que l’Italie, la Grèce et la Roumanie dépensent le moins.

**Impact** – La majorité des fonds est destinée aux écoles, plus de 70 % des dépenses éducatives couvrant les écoles pré-primaires, primaires et secondaires. Investir dans l’éducation est important car cela pourrait permettre aux économies européennes de croître de 8 à 10 % d’ici 2030 si plus de personnes acquièrent des compétences de base. De plus, les personnes plus éduquées gagnent généralement plus : une année scolaire supplémentaire peut augmenter le revenu de 7 %.

**Prochaines étapes** – La Commission européenne encourage les pays à continuer d’investir dans l’éducation, surtout pour préparer les jeunes aux emplois futurs. Cela est important car la population européenne vieillit, ce qui signifie moins de travailleurs et plus de pression sur les services publics. Une meilleure éducation peut aider à maintenir la force des économies malgré ces changements.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les pays de l’UE augmentent leurs dépenses en éducation après la pandémie pour améliorer les compétences et soutenir la croissance économique, mais davantage d’investissements restent nécessaires pour retrouver les niveaux d’avant la crise.
articles.personality_title_es: Los países de la UE aumentan el gasto en educación pero aún no alcanzan niveles previos a la pandemia
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Tras la pandemia de Covid-19, muchos países de la Unión Europea (UE) redujeron el gasto público en educación. Un nuevo informe muestra que estos países están invirtiendo más nuevamente para apoyar a las escuelas y estudiantes.

**Qué pasó** – La Comisión Europea publicó el 28 de agosto de 2025 un informe llamado «Invertir en Educación 2025». Encontró que los países de la UE gastaron un total de 806 mil millones de euros en educación en 2023. En promedio, la educación representó el 9,6 % del gasto público y el 4,7 % de la economía de cada país (PIB). Austria gasta un poco menos del 10 % del dinero público en educación, colocándola en la parte baja-media en comparación con otros países. Estonia, Suecia y Letonia gastan más, mientras que Italia, Grecia y Rumania gastan menos.

**Impacto** – La mayor parte del dinero va a las escuelas, con más del 70 % del gasto educativo destinado a escuelas preescolares, primarias y secundarias. Invertir en educación es importante porque puede ayudar a que las economías europeas crezcan entre un 8 y un 10 % para 2030 si más personas adquieren habilidades básicas. Además, las personas con más educación suelen ganar más dinero: un año extra de estudios puede aumentar los ingresos en un 7 %.

**Próximos pasos** – La Comisión Europea anima a los países a seguir invirtiendo en educación, especialmente para preparar a los jóvenes para los trabajos del futuro. Esto es importante porque la población de Europa está envejeciendo, lo que significa menos trabajadores y más presión sobre los servicios públicos. Una mejor educación puede ayudar a mantener fuertes las economías a pesar de estos cambios.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los países de la UE están aumentando el gasto en educación tras la pandemia para mejorar habilidades y apoyar el crecimiento económico, pero aún se necesita más inversión para alcanzar niveles anteriores a la crisis.
